data.title: Fix String::is_valid_integer() for single symbols + and -
data.body: Before: print("+".is_valid_integer()) return True, after: False. Please review it's my first little commit.

data.title: TextEdit::insert_text_at_cursor() doesn't work?
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Mac OS X 10.11.6 - Godot-master

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I'm attempting to build a Command box _a la_ Valve's Source engine. When the TextEdit node receives an "Enter" action, I process the command. The problem is, if the cursor isn't placed at the end of the command, it places an unwanted newline character. Since this is supposed to accept multiple lines, I can't clean out all `\n` entirely.

So I grab the position of the cursor before processing the command and select the newline (which works according to `get_selection_text()`), but when I use `insert_text_at_cursor()`, nothing happens and the string is untouched.

However, [I take a look at the code](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/scene/gui/text_edit.cpp#L3206) and see nothing wrong, hence the question mark in the title.

**Steps to reproduce:**  
1. Connect TextEdit node to `InputEvent()` signal
2. Receive an "Enter" action
3. Grab cursor position and select the newline
4. Erase selection by using `insert_text_at_cursor()`
5. Test it by entering any string and placing the cursor anywhere but the end
6. Press Enter/Return

**Link to minimal example project**:
https://db.tt/u58X6rku

If you're using the example project, just go to steps 5 and 6.

data.title: Autocomplete for functions after "if"
data.body:
**Operating system or device:** Windows 10 - **Godot version:** Godot Engine 2.1-rc1

**Issue description (what happened, and what was expected):**
If we define a function and try to call it earlier in the script after the "if" keyword, its name won't be suggested in the autocomplete window. It should autocomplete anywhere in the script. Screenshots:

**Autocompletes anywhere in the script without "if"**
![funcfuzzy1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19325565/17271444/581aae06-5695-11e6-8b79-32577cd6fa64.PNG)
![funcfuzzy2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19325565/17271451/9b64e852-5695-11e6-85fb-96958ca161ae.PNG)
**But when called after "if", it works only if we try to call it after it's declared:**
![funcfuzzy3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19325565/17271470/0ac41362-5696-11e6-88c7-fe4db9ef617f.PNG)
![funcfuzzy4](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19325565/17271473/2e2ab23e-5696-11e6-8b81-b86a5e22c74a.PNG)

**Steps to reproduce:**
Define a function. Try to call it after the "if" keyword before the line where it's declared

data.title: GDscript keywords are automatically replaced by something irrelevant
data.body:
_This is a generalised version of the #5964_ 
After posting issue #5964 and seeing @rgrams 's comment, I decided to look a little bit more into the problem. 

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows(does not matter), Godot 2.1RC1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Whenever you type a keyword(`pass`, `true`, ...) the editor suggests another unrelated function or constant. This problem is especially irritating if the keyword is followed by a newline because it automatically replaces the keyword in question.
I went through most GDscript key word and noted what happened
The results: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1nfh7Pw-5Qts0CBBN3okk6Y8CDsofJLlC07oTZfL6Wxo/edit?usp=sharing
Turns out, the engine never suggests any keyword and sometimes replaces them with surprising results...

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
example with `return` :
![ss](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20727749/17269792/a989e240-5652-11e6-8fdb-0e4b06816a30.jpg)

PS: this should be a quick fix, I hope it makes into RC2 or 2.1 stable :)

data.title: false error: Index p_contact_idx out of size
data.body:
Operating system: Windows 8.1 (64-bit) 
Godot version: Godot_v2.1_rc1_win64

Issue description: Godot_v2.0.3_stable_win64 seems to run this code just fine, but in Godot_v2.1_rc1_win64 it creates an error.

error: `Index p_contact_idx out of size (body->contact_count).`

I'm pretty sure I'm not out of index, because my index is coming from get_colliding_bodies(), and it works fine in 2.0.3. (or it could be my code, idk)  

code:

```
func _integrate_forces(state):

    for i in get_colliding_bodies():
        if i in get_tree().get_nodes_in_group("wallSlide"): 
            print(i.get_name())

            var vec_0 = state.get_contact_local_normal(get_colliding_bodies().find(i))          
            set_linear_velocity(vec_0 * speedCassV.length()/1.45 + speedCassV  )
            turnWithMovement()
            return
```

screen-cap: http://i.imgur.com/Z9CUDsq.jpg

data.title: Plugin reload doesn't keeps variables
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.1 rc1, Windows 10 64 bits

I make a plugin which has a custom button in the spatial menu. However, as soon as I save my tool as I edit it, Godot reloads it (which is fine), but member variables get reset to their initial state rather than their previous state.
Because of this, my custom button is back to null once reloaded, the plugin is left completely unusable or in a wrong state, and I have to restart the editor as in 2.0.4 old days.

Here is a test project:
[PluginReload.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/391639/PluginReload.zip)
It contains a plugin which edits a 3D Terrain custom node. 
- Click on the Terrain: observe a custom button appears in the menu.
- Make it so terrain_plugin.gd is reloaded by editing the script
- Click on another node, then the Terrain again: observe a Nil error in the console. The reference the plugin had on the button has been lost.

data.title: remove_control_from_container() is missing
data.body: In Godot 2.1 rc1, the EditorPlugin API has a function to add controls to containers, `add_control_from_container(int container, Control control)`, but I don't see a `remove_control_from_container(int container, Control control)`. Is it missing?

data.title: More tools for tiles
data.body:
Putting together tilemaps in godot is painful. Mainly because there's simply not enough tools to do it quickly and efficiently. I'll just give some ideas: 

**Automatic tileset from a texture** - relying on addons for such basic functionality isn't great. Besides, tile cutting addons don't have a lot of features (like tile naming or setting up collision) that should be there. Right now making a tileset in godot with it's default functionality should be considered a torture. 

**Randomizer** - If user selects more than one tile from the set, randomizer should kick in and randomly place one of the selected tiles on click. A lot of games use several variations of one tile so it's common to need some kind of randomization. In additional options it would be nice to have rotated and flipped tiles to appear randomly.

**Tile Animation** - this is the big HUGE one. Some tiles are just supposed to be animated. Water, for example. Right now doing animation requires either setting up timer to go through each tile and update it, or making a shader for animating those. Neither of those is good and a lot of times more costly than it should be. Having some sort of mechanism for tile animation without a huge fuss would be great. 

**TileMap collision to NavMap** - a lot of the times, if you do collisions on your tiles, you might want to have a navmap from those collisions.

_These ones are not as important but still would be a nice addition:_

**Brush size** - maybe tiles are small. Maybe map is big. Maybe someone wants to do big strokes before making a more detailed map. Without brush size option you either put one tile at a time or bucket fill it all. 

**Less whitespace between tiles** - tiles don't need to take up so much space in tile picker and have huge margins. The more tiles you have on screen the easier it's to find the one you need.

data.title: Explicitly initialize 'pending_auto_reload' to false.
data.body: Makes sure the 'pending_auto_reload' variable is initalized to false. Fixes a bug where the script sync between editor and game runtime wouldn't signal a script reload if the variable auto-initalized to true.

data.title: wrong focus zone for mouse wheel events on HSlider
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1beta official w64
2.0.4.1 official w64
windows 8.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

When you rotate the mouse wheel over a HSlider, it shows it has the focus but mouse wheel has no effect.

For the mouse wheel have an effect, you have to put the mouse in a zone above the Hslider.

When you have several Hsliders in a grid, that's the Hslider below the one with focus which receive mouse wheel events.

See animated GIF.

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
![hslider_focus_mousewheel](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9801802/17248211/507a7e08-5599-11e6-99da-ac7e6f8b3dd8.gif)

data.title: Button pressed stylebox for toggle mode
data.body:
Current button pressed stylebox does not work well for toggle mode.
Toggled button is almost indistinguishable from non-pressed one.
Current style works fine for normal press events when there is noticable change from hover style on press.
I've created more contrastive style to use in my project still I'm not sure if it's not too dark for normal buttons - there is very big color change on press.
Simplest solution would be to find some better more contrastive style.
Or maybe there is a need for having additional TOGGLED style? But it needs more work.
Also we could allow the engine to be used by persons with better sight than mine. :P

Screenshot, so you can see the problem (?), the same buttons are toggled in both relevant groups:
![button_pressed_theme](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19764492/17243711/7bd1937c-557e-11e6-9e6e-5659decdc42d.png)

My darker stylebox image:
![button_pressed](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19764492/17243435/19247164-557d-11e6-8696-bd108de6501b.png)

data.title: Prevent Godot from crashing when making a loop in scene system
data.body:
This bug might be possible to do on every version of Godot

**Description:**

A scene has another scene as a child.
If you put to this child a child that is his parent, it will crash
`e.g : "game.tscn" has" settings.tscn" as a child, "settings.tscn" has "game.tscn" as a child`

If a scene is _connected to one of the two scenes_, it will not be playable or editable.
The game will simply crash and the editor will too (_excepted if it's the first scene loaded,it will then just show an error message_).

Also, if you put this scene or one of the two that are creating the loop in the script editor
`e.g : preload("node_not_working.tscn")`
_it will fail to check the existence of the scene_ and **crash**.

There are only two ways of fixing this : 
- having made backups
- not using a binary format to save files, for you can edit the xml by yourslef

I know this is a very dumb case, but it can happen while not watching when using the auto-fix of depencies, and then totally break a project.

data.title: Endless stream of errors in 2.1rc1 high DPI
data.body:
On Windows 10, v2.1rc1, high dpi 2K display:

Launching the old Godot 2.0.x works fine. Completely not working in 2.1rc1. I get an endless (literally) stream of errors in the terminal that opens with Godot.

Set Godot to launch in high DPI mode in the settings, relaunch, and this should happen (never works again). I am on a 2736x1824 at 267 PPI display.

[Error dump on gist](https://gist.github.com/Qudware/6807a3bf9c52e965cdb2c6687e0e41c7)

I should note that after ~8 mins it opens the project manager, when selecting a project it completely crashes!

data.title: Sprites for some tiles are swapped
data.body:
This is really irritating, and I'm not sure what I've done to cause it.

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 - Godot 2.0.4.1.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When placing tiles in a tilemap, some tiles in the tile selection menu/palette actually result in totally different tiles being placed on the map. The name and thumbnail is that of one tile, but placing the tile in the map results in a different one.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a scene and populate it with sprites.
2. Convert the scene to a tileset (any format)
3. Create a new scene and create a tilemap.
4. Load the previously created tileset.
5. Proceed through the list of tiles. Some of them do not look like their thumbnail once placed.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
I've attached an example project with a single scene demonstrating the issue.
I have attempted to place two tiles, one called `fgSlantL` and the other called `fgSlopeR`. You can see what these tiles are supposed to look like in the thumbnail. However, when I actually place them, `fgSlantL` looks like `fgSlopeR` and vice versa.

[StarsBelow.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/388068/StarsBelow.zip)

data.title: (Auto-)update of assets
data.body:
As mentioned in the (RIP) #4279 :
It would be nice to have a way to update assets that were installed from the asset library. That would require storing asset information (as an url probably), and maybe a list of selected folders from the asset. Then, when a button is clicked, or some time after the editor is started, we can check for updates to the said assets (by comparing the version id properties), and notify the user if it is so.

WDYT?
